BE11:15am

SIG has issued a trading update covering the first half of the year. It revealed that revenues from continuing operations fell 5.7% (January-April: -3.4%) with LFL revenues declining 3.8% (January-April: -2.6%). Hence the pace of decline in underlying revenues accelerated in May/June with SIG specifically noting “a marked deterioration in the level of construction activity in the UK as the year has progressed”.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

However, in its outlook comments, SIG once again suggested that its expectations for underlying profitability for the year overall remain unchanged, although it “will continue to monitor how trading conditions develop”. In addition, SIG has announced the disposal of a raised access flooring business to Kingspan for circa £12m while the review of the Air Handling division is ongoing. It also indicated that net debt continues to fall.

BE11:16am

We noted previously that the pressure on the top-line underlined the importance of self-help for SIG. This clearly remains the case. Importantly, there was a stepchange in SIG’s operating profit in H2 2018 due to a meaningful reduction in the group’s cost base as the benefits from cutting management layers and reducing headcount started to come through. SIG will gain from the annualised effect of this in 2019.
We will review forecasts following the update. Current assumptions of note include a LFL revenue decline of 1% for 2019 overall, but the group’s underlying trading margin is anticipated to improve towards 4%. In the context of the LFL decline of 3.8% in H1, our revenue estimate looks too optimistic – especially in the UK. Hence this will need to be offset by margin gains.

BE11:16am

UK & Ireland LFL revenues declined 12.7% in H1 (-9.2% between January and April), implying a sharp weakening in May and June. LFL revenues in the core SIG Distribution (SIGD) business fell 17% (January-April: -15%). According to SIG, the latter was attributable to two factors. The first was the falling level of construction, a trend that became more pronounced in Q2, while there was also the continuing impact of the withdrawal from unprofitable business. The latter has been a focus of SIG in recent times.
In Mainland Europe, LFL revenues increased 3.3% in H1 (+2.7% in the first four months of the year). France LFL revenues were up 3.3% (January-April: +1.9%), a good performance given there was a ransomware attack during the period. In Germany, LFL revenues were slightly up (+0.1%), having been flat between January and April. Elsewhere, LFL revenues increased 6.3% in Poland (January-April: +9.8%); rose 7.7% in Air Handling (January-April: +5.2%); and fell 1.3% in the Benelux (January-April: +0.9%).
In relation to the review of strategic options for the Air Handling division, there is no new information with a further update to be provided in due course. However, the sale of WeGo FloorTec GmBH, a German manufacturer of raised access flooring, has been announced. It contributed operating profit of around £2m last year and the disposal proceeds will be circa £12m. Kingspan is to acquire the business.
Debt reduction remains, unsurprisingly, a priority and reportedly fell further in H1. SIG has reiterated that it is on course to reduce leverage (net debt/EBITDA) to below 1x over the medium term (1.7x at end-2018). Our model currently envisages net debt/EBITDA falling to 1.3x by year-end.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

And Canaccord.

red yup poland is still rocking
BE11:17am

The trading update points to a clear deterioration in trading in the UK in Q2. LFL sales in
the UK remain very weak and have clearly worsened during May and June. Wet weather
may not have helped as well as a tougher comparative but recent PMI data suggests
underlying trading has deteriorated. Europe looks stable with a bounce back for France
in May and June, after a difficult start to the year. At this point management expects to
deliver full year profit expectations, "but will continue to monitor how trading conditions
develop". It looks like the H1:H2 profit split would be c.36%:64% in order to meet the
consensus PBT of c.£86m, which looks demanding given trading in May and June.
Self-help continues to progress well with gross margins improving and costs being cut,
which is reassuring assuming LFL sales stabilise soon. A non-core disposal will help
net debt but leverage looks likely to be c.1.2 times using our 2019E estimates; clearly,
the disposal of Air Handling would radically change the leverage picture. Management
continues to deliver self-help but is not seeing any market tailwinds and consensus
numbers appear to remain under pressure (we think the top end is likely to at least come
down towards c.£85m PBT today) with nervousness around the UK trading outlook likely
to increase with this update. We reiterate our HOLD rating and recently reduced price
target of 138p.

BE11:19am

With regards Persimmon -- currently the FTSE 100's sharpest faller -- some of the wires are pinning it to a Citi target downgrade.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

PT trimmed to £24.46, Remain Buyers Group's margin performance continues to be robust despite the headwinds on cost inflation, additional costs on customer care and specification, supporting superior returns. We believe the slowdown in outlet openings is a temporary issue as the group works to improve quality standards. The additional investment in WIP and the significant increase in units under construction suggests that the phasing issue is likely to normalize at some point in 2020 driving stronger volume delivery and supporting healthy FCF generation on a steady basis. Stock trades on a P/B of 2.05x for 2019e with projected RoE of c.28% and offers D/Y of c.12%. Although sector's cyclical risks may persist pending clarity around Brexit, some of these concerns on customer quality and margin performance are likely unwind over the next 12-18 months driving a re-rating to better reflect the group's superior returns and FCFs in our view.

BE11:27am

this will be the last employment report before the FOMC meeting at the end of this month for which markets are pricing in 33bps of cuts as of this morning.
As our economists noted in their preview, what today’s report says about the trends in hiring and income growth could meaningfully impact market expectations so expect there to be just as much focus on hours and wages as the headline payrolls reading. In terms of expectations both our economists and the consensus peg payrolls at 160k. As a reminder, the May print was a much softer than expected 75k which dragged down the three-month trailing average to 151k. Our colleagues note that from the Fed’s perspective, the year-over-year trend in private employment is more important as this needs to outpace the trend in labor force growth in order to keep downward pressure on the unemployment rate. As Cleveland Fed President Mester reminded us recently, monthly payroll gains in the 75k – 120k range would still be consistent with the underlying trend in overall output growth. As for the rest of the report, the consensus expects the unemployment rate to hold steady at 3.6%, earnings to rise +0.3% mom and hours to hold at 34.4. Our economists also expect earnings to rise +0.3% which should result in a one-tenth increase in the year-over-year rate to +3.2%, however they do expect hours to tick up to 34.5.

red goldilocks is about 90-100k wages 0.2%

BE11:29am

US Non-Farm Payrolls at 1330 represents one of the pieces of data set to frame the rate-cutting options of the FOMC at the July meeting. As we have warned in recent months, there are a broad range of indicators showing capacity constraints in the US labor market, meaning that a single month’s NFP print poses questions over whether demand or supply impairment is constraining growth. The diagnosis is key for assessing the most suitable monetary policy response.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Our view on the US economy – indeed much of the developed world – stems back to our Q3 2018 outlook where we flagged that with spare capacity that emerged after the Financial Crisis has now largely being used up. Growth, going forward, is more reliant on productivity and supply-side improvements. Now it may be that the FOMC will bow to market and political pressure and instigate a precautionary rate cut cycle regardless - however we remain of the view that correct ppraisal of what is slowing US growth is necessary before committing to a sustained policy path. That the bond market has concluded that a sustained easing cycle is a near-certainty, means that the value is in leaning against the pricing that this has created.

red as for evidence, for uk sales, the move during the 30 mins per release always marked the direction of the data swing.

11:38 am

Goldman incoming:

BE11:39am

Hexagon pre-announced 2Q19 results with revenues and EBIT coming in significantly below expectations. Organic revenue growth for 2Q19 came in at -1% yoy vs Infront consensus at 4.5% yoy. We note that this is the first negative quarterly organic growth reported by Hexagon in the last 10 years. According to the company, the main driver for the miss was weakness in China (c.15% of Hexagon revenues) due to the impact of geopolitical uncertainties on global trade. The weakness was mainly in the electronics business, negatively impacting the Manufacturing Intelligence division. Based on our calculations, assuming all the other segments grew inline with our expectations, the manufacturing intelligence division would have declined low double digits in 2Q19 (vs GSe: 6% yoy). We await details on how this business is expected to track going forward at the full 2Q19 results on July 26. Further, we note that management has taken restructuring actions specifically reducing the global workforce by 700 employees, which would result in one-off charge of €44 mn in 2Q19 and is expected to drive annualised cost savings of €51 mn by end-2020.

BE11:40am

And Barclays.

Sultan of swaps wow first negative organic growth in 10yrs
11:40 am
BE11:40am

[Manufacturing Intelligence] has seen exceptional growth over recent years due to the boom in high-end smartphone manufacture and, understandably, the business has proven not to be immune from the recent turbulence in the region and in global trade negotiations. Demand within the other segments has been broadly stable with previous expectations.

BE11:40am

The slowing in Hexagon’s electronics manufacturing business in China is in line with warnings and statements elsewhere within the semiconductor and electronics food chain. The addition of Huawei to the U.S. Department of Commerce’s Entity List in May had a near immediate impact on Huawei’s ability to source U.S. components, driving a raft of warnings across the semi space in late May/early June. Since then, we have seen the impact spread further through the supply chain, both in terms of Huawei’s own manufacturing levels and those of its competitors. Major Hexagon customer Foxconn manufacturers smartphones for Huawei as well as Apple and Xiaomi, to name but three. In early June, the South China Morning Post reported that Foxconn had “stopped several production lines for Huawei phones” due to order reductions. Huawei refuted these initial claims but by late June had acknowledged the U.S. actions would result in its 2019 revenue being about 20% below its prior target (US$100bn vs. 125bn).

Organic growth in the second quarter turned negative and declined by ~1% organically, versus company expectations of 4.5% growth. Preliminary reporting indicates 3% organic growth for GES and a 5% decline in IES, while EBIT is expected to be €237m, missing consensus by 8%. The company will take measures to bring the company back on track to meet its 2021 targets including a reduction in its workforce by 700 employees leading to a one-off charge of €44m and annualised cost savings of €51 by the end of next year. While this will help the margin progression towards the 27-28% target, the market is focused on 5% organic growth target, which is clearly called into question.

It also appears that the weakness was in June, not for the whole quarter. The key question will therefore be the extent to which a full quarter impact will drag Q3 to a more negative growth rate and whether this will be, to some extent, a temporary impact or something which will weigh on the group for the coming four quarters.

BE11:41am

Hexagon is more exposed than most to China, at about 15% of group revenue I think.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Key commodity indicators in China have been slowing/weak (PMIs, floorspace starts/sales, infrastructureFAI, autos). Discussions on our recent China trip suggest that, while officials have room to adjust policy if needed, the preferred course is to mitigate the slowdown rather thantry to generate a big cyclical upswing, while a broader easing of credit risks is inflating property prices further.Seasonally, demand falls over the summer months and this year in particular there has been a large impact on demand from weather-related events in southern China (floods and hot weather).

BE11:53am

t’s hard to get away from iron ore exposure among theliquidlarge-cap miners. We prefer BHP (OW) given superior commodity mix, growth, diversification, margins and ROEs vs. RIO(UW). Sentiment towardsGlencore (OW) remains weak and earnings look vulnerable into Q2 (see Headwinds into results, 27 June). We are holding out for a strategy reboot once the management transition completes and for a DOJ settlement. We remainUW ANTO given what we see as very expensive valuations, a range-bound outlook for copper vs valuation implying significant increases, and almost zero FCF generation over the next five years at spot.

BE12:00pm

While there are headwinds to reducing year end net debt materially in FY20 (eg social housing retained liability costs, Phase 2 transformation costs) there could be a meaningful reduction in average net debt following the resolution of the 1H FY19 collections issues resulting in 4Q19 average net debt being £31m lower than 4Q18. The CFO is targeting a reduction in the difference between average and year end net debt leverage from 1.5x in FY19 to 1.0x in FY20. If achieved this could result in FY20 average net debt leverage of 2.3x (FY19 2.8x), approaching the 2.0x medium-term target. Underlying leverage (average net debt plus ancillary financing) was higher than we would like to see in FY19 at 3.6x (FY18 3.8x). However, if the targeted reduction in average net debt and ancillary finance is delivered then underlying FY20 leverage could be down to 3.0x (significantly better than the 4.6x of FY17).
Valuation: We set fair value at 145p (from 125p), equivalent to 8.2x FY20E EPS and 6.3x FY20E EBITDA, in aggregate a 20% discount (25% previously) to the Numis Smaller Companies Index. The reduction in the discount applied reflects the expectation that the improvement in average net debt experienced in 4Q will be sustained throughout FY20

John Menzies PLC (MNZS:LSE): Last: 397.00, down 61 (-13.32%), High: 400.48, Low: 353.50, Volume: 1.12m
BE12:04pm

Another "deterioration in June" story.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Here's Numis to summarise.

BE12:05pm

After a reasonable first four months' trading, Menzies has been impacted in MayJune by the weakening macro environment, which has significantly impacted cargo volumes, and to a lesser extent flight schedules. The H1 performance has been below expectations and management believes that full-year operating profit will not exceed that of 2018 (£55.1m). We have reduced our 2019 EBITA forecast by 13% to £54.1m and our 2020-21 EBITA forecasts by 5% to £66.4m and £73.3m respectively. Though we believe that underlying progress is being made operationally at Menzies, which will deliver superior medium-term financial performance, in the short term this has been more than offset by the macro.

BE12:05pm

We expect profits in the current year to be more 2H-weighted, with 1H EBITA of around £17m (1H18 £20.9m), and around £37m in 2H (2H18 £34.4m) owing to a full six-month benefit of the Airline Services acquisition, the start of the cost savings, the return of flights to Saint Marten (impacted by hurricane Irma) and the full year impact of better trading in the Americas. We assume that this improved momentum, together with a more favourable cargo volume backdrop, deliver the strong growth in profits we forecast for 2020.

BE12:11pm

Aquis is buying NEX Exchange for £1 (plus net working
capital on the balance sheet). Management expectations of profitability in 2020 are not changed by this transaction, though the acquired business is forecast to lose £1m over the next two years. Aquis' intention is to use its technology to enhance liquidity and so create a more competitive and attractive listing venue. Our unchanged TP implies 25% upside, based off continuing progress to a 10% market share.

12:11 pm
BE12:11pm

They're shop. Of course.

BE12:12pm

This acquisition will strengthen Aquis' position as a leading exchange services group and is a first step into creating a pan-European Listing Exchange.

BE12:12pm

The deal is expected to enhance shareholder value in the medium term. This adds to an already exciting story. Aquis is disrupting the trading landscape and continuing to gain market share.

12:12 pm
BE12:12pm

NEX is one of only four primary equity listing venues in London. This gives Aquis the ability to disrupt the IPO market and could be valuable if a consolidated tape is introduced.

We leave forecasts unchanged until
the acquisition is completed
(expected in September). Our TP is
based on 20x the 30p earnings from
10% market share. Our TP of 606p
